description: Stone tools - found in present-day Kenya, they are so old that only a pre-human species could have invented them. The otherwise earliest known stone tools (Oldowan) were found in Ethiopia developed perhaps by Australopithecus garhi or Homo habilis[further explanation needed]
Earliest likely control of fire and cooking, by Homo habilis
Acheulean stone tools in Kenya by Homo erectus
Varying estimates for the origin of language
Bone tools in Africa
Boats
Hafting in South Africa
Woodworking construction in Zambia
Pigments in Zambia
Spears in Germany likely by Homo heidelbergensis
The trade and long-distance transportation of resources (e.g. obsidian), use of pigments, and possible making of projectile points in Kenya
Early stone-tipped projectile weapons in Ethiopia

Glue in Central Italy by Neanderthals. More complicated compound adhesives developed by Homo sapiens have been found from c. 70 kya Sibudu, South Africa and have been regarded as a sign of cognitive advancement.
Beds in South Africa.
Clothing (among anatomically modern humans in Africa). Some other evidence suggests that humans may have begun wearing clothing as far back as 100
Beads in Israel and Algeria
Compound paints made in South Africa
Funerals (in the form of burial) in Israel
Harpoons in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Oldest arrows (and evidence of bow-and-arrow technology), and oldest needle, at Sibudu, South Africa
Cave painting in Spain by Neanderthal
Ground stone tools - fragments of an axe in Australia date to 49-45 ka, more appear in Japan closer to 30 ka, and elsewhere closer to the Neolithic.
The oldest-known mines in the world are from Eswatini, and extracted hematite for the production of the red pigment ochre.

Earliest evidence of shoes, suggested by changes in foot bone morphology in China by Tianyuan Man. The earliest physical shoes found so far are bark sandals dated to 10 to 9 kya in Fort Rock Cave, United States.
Tally sticks (see Lebombo bone) in Eswatini
Flute in Germany
Mortar and pestle in Southwest Asia
Weaving - Indirect evidence from Moravia and Georgia. The earliest actual piece of woven cloth was found in Çatalhöyük, Turkey.
Star chart in France and Spain
Rope
Ceramics in Europe
Domestication of the dog in Siberia.
Fishing hook in Okinawa Island modern day Japan.
Pottery in China
Bread in Jordan
Agriculture in the Fertile Crescent
Domestication of sheep in Southwest Asia (followed shortly by pigs, goats and cattle)
Domestication of rice in China
Oldest known surviving building - Göbekli Tepe
Mudbricks, and clay mortar in Jericho.
Oldest known water well in Cyprus.
Proto-city - large permanent settlements, such as Tell es-Sultan (Jericho) and Çatalhöyük, Turkey.
Alcohol fermentation - specifically mead
Sled dog and Dog sled
Tanned leather in Mehrgarh
Evidence of lead smelting in Çatalhöyük
Kiln in Mesopotamia (Iraq)
Proto-writing in present-day Egypt, Iraq, Romania, China, India and Pakistan.
Sailing - pottery depictions of sail boats
Copper smelting in Serbia
Seawall in Tel Hreiz.
Lacquer in China
Cotton thread
column5: connecting the copper beads of a bracelet.

description: Rowing oars in China
Lost-wax casting in Israel or the Indus Valley
Fired bricks in China.
Paved roads
article_length: in and around the Mesopotamian city of Ur

description: Plumbing. The earliest pipes were made of clay
article_length: and are found at the Temple of Bel at Nippur in Babylonia.[nb 2]

description: Wheel: potter's wheels in Mesopotamia and wheeled vehicles in Mesopotamia (Sumerian civilization)
article_length: the Northern Caucasus (Maykop culture) and Central Europe (Cucuteni-Trypillia culture).

description: Silk garments (sericulture) in China
Probable first domestication of the horse in the Eurasian Steppes.
Wine as general anesthesia in Sumer.
Seal (emblem) invented around in the Near East
article_length: at the contemporary sites of Uruk in southern Mesopotamia and slightly later at Susa in south-western Iran during the Proto-Elamite period
page_url: and they follow the development of stamp seals in the Halaf culture or slightly earlier.

description: Ploughing
column6: has also been found at Kalibangan

description: Tattoos in southern Europe
Writing - in Sumer and Egypt.
City in Uruk
Dry Latrines in the city of Uruk
column5: that added raised fired brick foot platforms
column7: all over clay pipe constructed drains.

description: Devices functionally equivalent to dice
article_length: in the form of flat two-sided throwsticks
page_url: are seen in the Egyptian game of Senet. Perhaps the oldest known dice
column6: were excavated as part of a backgammon-like game set at the Burnt City
column7: an archeological site in south-eastern Iran
column8: estimated to be from between 2800 and 2500 BC. Later
column9: terracotta dice were used at the Indus Valley site of Mohenjo-daro (modern-day Pakistan).

description: Tin extraction in Central Asia
Papyrus in Egypt
Reservoir in Girnar
Receipt in Ancient Mesopotamia (Iraq)
Rhinoplasty in Egypt.
The Ruler
Planned city in Indus Valley (modern-day: India
Public sewage and sanitation systems in Indus Valley sites such as Mohenjo-daro and Rakhigarhi (modern-day: India
Public bath in Mohenjo-daro
Levee in Indus Valley.
Balance weights and scales
article_length: from the Fourth Dynasty of Egypt; examples of Deben (unit) balance weights
page_url: from reign of Sneferu (c. 2600 BC) have been attributed.

description: Docks structure in Wadi al-Jarf
page_url: which was developed by the reign of the Pharaoh Khufu. [nb 4]

description: Puppetry in the Indus Valley.
Fork in Bronze Age Qijia culture in China
Copper pipes
page_url: an adjoining temple complex at Abusir
column5: was discovered to have a network of copper drainage pipes.

description: Touchstone in the Indus Valley site of Banawali (modern-day India).
Dictionary in Mesopotamia.
Protractor
column6: a Xancus shell cylinder with sawn grooves
column8: in its top and bottom surfaces
column9: has been proposed as an angle marking tool.

description: Water clock by at least the old Babylonian period (c. 2000 - c. 1600 BC)
article_length: but possibly earlier from Mohenjo-Daro in the Indus Valley.

description: Chariot in Russia and Kazakhstan
Fountain in Lagash, Sumer
Scissors, in Mesopotamia.
Proto-alphabet (Proto-Sinaitic script) in Egypt.
Surgical treatise appeared in Egypt.
Sundial in Ancient Egypt or Babylonia (modern-day Iraq).
Glass manufacture in either Mesopotamia or Ancient Egypt
Seed drill in Babylonia
Rubber, Mesoamerican ballgame.

Concrete in Tiryns (Mycenaean Greece). Waterproof concrete was later developed by the Assyrians in 688 BC, and the Romans developed concretes that could set underwater. The Romans later used concrete extensively for construction from 300 BC to 476 AD.
Lathe in Ancient Egypt
Iron smelting in the Hittite Empire of the Middle East.
Distillation is described on Akkadian tablets documenting perfumery operations.
Saddle (fringed cloths or pads used by Assyrian cavalry)
Crossbow in China.
Windmills in Persia
Coins in Phoenicia (Modern Lebanon) or Lydia
Wagonway called Diolkos across the Isthmus of Corinth in Ancient Greece
High Carbon Steel, produced by the Closed Crucible method, later known as Wootz steel, of South India.
University in Taxila, of the Indus Valley, then part of the kingdom of Gandhara, of the Achaemenid Empire (modern-day Pakistan).
Systematization of medicine and surgery in the Sushruta Samhita in Vedic Northern India.
Crank motion (rotary quern) in Carthage or 5th century BC Celtiberian Spain Later during the Roman empire, a mechanism appeared that incorporated a connecting rod.
Loan deeds in Upanishadic India.
Crane in Ancient Greece
Lighthouse in Greece
Toe stirrup, depicted in 2nd century Buddhist art, of the Sanchi and Bhaja Caves, of the Deccan Satavahana empire (modern-day India) although may have originated as early as 500 BC.
Catapult by Ajatashatru in Magadha, India.
Scythed chariot by Ajatashatru in Magadha, India.

Cast iron in Ancient China: Confirmed by archaeological evidence, the earliest cast iron is developed in China by the early 5th century BC during the Zhou Dynasty (1122-256 BC), the oldest specimens found in a tomb of Luhe County in Jiangsu province.
Spiral stairs (Temple A) in Selinunte, Sicily (see also List of ancient spiral stairs)
Early descriptions of what may be a Wheelbarrow in Greece. First actual depiction of one (tomb mural) shows up in China in 118 AD.
Camera obscura described by Mo-tzu (or Mozi) in China.
Traction trebuchet in Ancient China.
Gears in Ancient China
Reed pens, utilising a split nib, were used to write with ink on Papyrus in Egypt.
Nailed Horseshoe, with 4 bronze shoes found in an Etruscan tomb.
Animal-driven rotary mill in Carthage.
Corporations in either the Maurya Empire of India or in Ancient Rome (Collegium).
Cheque in the Maurya Empire of India.
Potassium nitrate manufacturing and military use in the Seleucid Empire.
Formal systems by Pāṇini in India, possibly during the reign of Chandragupta Maurya.
Zinc production in North-Western India during the Maurya Empire.
Analog computers in the Hellenistic world (see e.g. the Antikythera mechanism), possibly in Rhodes.
Canal lock in Canal of the Pharaohs under Ptolemy II (283-246 BC) in Hellenistic Egypt
Cam during the Hellenistic period, used in water-driven automata.

Water wheel. The origin is unclear: Indian Pali texts dating to the 4th century BCE refer to the cakkavattaka, which later commentaries describe as arahatta-ghati-yanta (machine with wheel-pots attached). Helaine Selin suggests that the device existed in Persia before 350 BC. The clearest description of the water wheel and Liquid-driven escapement is provided by Philo of Byzantium (c. 280 - 220 BC) in the Hellenistic kingdoms.
Gimbal described by Philo of Byzantium
Dry dock under Ptolemy IV (221-205 BC) in Hellenistic Egypt
Blast furnace in Ancient China: The earliest discovered blast furnaces in China date to the 3rd and 2nd centuries BC, although most sites are from the later Han dynasty.
Paper in Han dynasty China
Compass in Han dynasty China
Astrolabe invented by Apollonius of Perga.
Segmental arch bridge (e.g. Pont-Saint-Martin or Ponte San Lorenzo) in Italy, Roman Republic
Arch dam (Glanum Dam) in Gallia Narbonensis, Roman Republic (see also List of Roman dams)
Trip hammer in China

An empty shell Glyph for zero, is found on a Maya numerals Stela, from Chiapa de Corzo, Chiapas. Independently invented by Claudius Ptolemy, in the second century CE Egypt, and appearing in the calculations of the Almagest.
Glass blowing developed in Jerusalem.
Reverse overshot water wheel by Roman engineers in Rio Tinto, Spain
Noodle in Lajia in China
The aeolipile, a simple steam turbine, is recorded by Hero of Alexandria.
Vending machines are invented by Hero of Alexandria.
The double-entry bookkeeping system is developed in the Roman Empire.

Seismometer and pendulum are developed in Han dynasty China, built by Zhang Heng. It is a large metal urn-shaped instrument which employed either a suspended pendulum or inverted pendulum acting on inertia, like the ground tremors from earthquakes, to dislodge a metal ball by a lever trip device.
Carding is invented in India.
Woodblock printing is invented in Han dynasty China sometime before 220 AD. This made China become the world's first print culture.
Water turbine is invented in the Roman Empire in modern-day Tunisia.
Chaturanga, a precursor of Chess, is invented in India during the Gupta Empire.
Roman Dichroic glass, which displays one of two different colors depending on lighting conditions.

Mariner's compass is invented in Tamil Southern India: the first mention of the use of a compass for navigational purposes is found in Tamil nautical texts as the macchayantra. However, the theoretical notion of magnets pointing North predates the device by several centuries.

Simple suspension bridge is independently invented in Pre-Columbian South America, and the Hindu Kush range, of present-day Afghanistan and Pakistan. With Han dynasty travelers noting bridges being constructed from 3 or more vines or 3 ropes. Later bridges constructed utilizing cables of iron chains appeared in Tibet.
Fishing reel is invented in Ancient China: In literary records, the earliest evidence of the fishing reel comes from a 4th-century AD work entitled Lives of Famous Immortals.
Oil Wells and Borehole drilling are developed in China. Such wells could reach depths of up to 240 m (790 ft).

The construction of the Iron pillar of Delhi in Mathura by the Gupta Empire shows the development of rust-resistant ferrous metallurgy in Ancient India, although original texts do not survive to detail the specific processes invented in this period.

The horse collar as a fully developed collar harness is developed in Southern and Northern Dynasties China during the 5th century AD. The earliest depiction of it is a Dunhuang cave mural from the Chinese Northern Wei Dynasty, the painting dated to 477-499.
Pointed arch bridge (Karamagara Bridge) is built in Cappadocia, Eastern Roman Empire
Incense clock is invented in China.
Charkha (spinning wheel/cotton gin) is invented in India (probably during the Vakataka dynasty of Maharashtra, India), between 500 and 1000 A.D.
Pendentive dome (Hagia Sophia) is built in Constantinople, Eastern Roman Empire
Sulfur matches exist in China.
Toilet paper is invented in Sui dynasty China, first mentioned by the official Yan Zhitui (531-591), with full evidence of continual use in subsequent dynasties.
Toothbrush is invented in China during the Tang Dynasty

Greek fire is invented in Constantinople, Byzantine Empire: Greek fire, an incendiary weapon likely based on petroleum or naphtha, is invented by Kallinikos, a Lebanese Greek refugee from Baalbek, as described by Theophanes. However, the historicity and exact chronology of this account is dubious, and it could be that Kallinikos merely introduced an improved version of an established weapon.

Banknote is invented in Tang dynasty China: The banknote is first developed in China during the Tang and Song dynasties, starting in the 7th century. Its roots are in merchant receipts of deposit during the Tang Dynasty (618-907), as merchants and wholesalers desire to avoid the heavy bulk of copper coinage in large commercial transactions.

Porcelain is invented in Tang dynasty China: True porcelain is manufactured in northern China from roughly the beginning of the Tang Dynasty in the 7th century, while true porcelain was not manufactured in southern China until about 300 years later, during the early 10th century.

Gunpowder is invented in Tang dynasty China: Gunpowder is, according to prevailing academic consensus, discovered in the 9th century by Chinese alchemists searching for an elixir of immortality. Evidence of gunpowder's first use in China comes from the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period (618-907). The earliest known recorded recipes for gunpowder are written by Zeng Gongliang, Ding Du, and Yang Weide in the Wujing Zongyao, a military manuscript compiled in 1044 during the Song Dynasty (960-1279).
Playing card is invented in Tang Dynasty China
Degree-granting university is established in Morocco

Fire lance is invented in Song dynasty China, developed in the 10th century with a tube of first bamboo and later on metal that shot a weak gunpowder blast of flame and shrapnel, its earliest depiction is a painting found at Dunhuang. Fire lance is the earliest firearm in the world and one of the earliest gunpowder weapons.

Fireworks are invented in Song dynasty China: Fireworks first appear in China during the Song Dynasty (960-1279), in the early age of gunpowder. Fireworks could be purchased from market vendors; these were made of sticks of bamboo packed with gunpowder.
Fountain pen: invented at the request of al-Mu'izz li-Din Allah in Arab Egypt.
Early versions of the Bessemer process are developed in China.
Endless power-transmitting chain drive by Su Song for the development an astronomical clock (the Cosmic Engine)
Movable type is invented in Song dynasty China: The first record of a movable type system is in the Dream Pool Essays, which attributes the invention of the movable type to Bi Sheng.
Ismail al-Jazari invents the elephant clock .
Rocket for military and recreational uses date back to at least 13th-century China.
The earliest form of mechanical escapement, the verge escapement in Europe.
Buttons (combined with buttonholes) as a functional fastening for closing clothes appear first in Germany.

Explosive bomb in Jin dynasty Manchuria: Explosive bombs are used in 1221 by the Jin dynasty against a Song Dynasty city. The first accounts of bombs made of cast iron shells packed with explosive gunpowder are documented in the 13th century in China and are called "thunder-crash bombs", coined during a Jin dynasty naval battle in 1231.

Hand cannon is invented in Yuan dynasty China: The earliest hand cannon dates to the 13th century based on archaeological evidence from a Heilongjiang excavation. There is also written evidence in the Yuanshi (1370) on Li Tang, an ethnic Jurchen commander under the Yuan Dynasty who in 1288 suppresses the rebellion of the Christian prince Nayan with his "gun-soldiers" or chongzu, this being the earliest known event where this phrase is used.
Worm gear cotton gin in India.

Land mine is invented in Song dynasty China: Textual evidence suggests that the first use of a land mine in history is by a Song Dynasty brigadier general known as Lou Qianxia, who uses an 'enormous bomb' (huo pao) to kill Mongol soldiers invading Guangxi in 1277.
Eyeglasses are invented in Italy
Multistage rocket is described in Huolongjing by Jiao Yu during the Ming dynasty China.
Cannon is invented in Ming dynasty China

Naval mine is invented in Ming dynasty China: Mentioned in the Huolongjing military manuscript written by Jiao Yu (fl. 14th to early 15th century) and Liu Bowen (1311-1375), describing naval mines used at sea or on rivers and lakes, made of wrought iron and enclosed in an ox bladder. A later model is documented in Song Yingxing's encyclopedia written in 1637.
Bidriware is invented in the Bahmani Sultanate in India.
Coil spring

Compound microscopes, which combine an objective lens with an eyepiece to view a real image, first appear in Europe. Apparently derived from the telescope, actual inventor unknown, variously attributed to Zacharias Janssen (his son claiming it was invented in 1590), Cornelis Drebbel, and Galileo Galilei.
Slide rule: invented by William Oughtred
Mechanical calculator. The Pascaline is built by Blaise Pascal.
Barometer: invented by Evangelista Torricelli, or possibly up to three years earlier by Gasparo Berti.
Vacuum pump: Invented by Otto von Guericke.
Pendulum clock: Invented by Christiaan Huygens. It was first conceptualized in 1637 by Galileo Galilei but he was unable to create a working model.
Friction machine: Invented by Otto von Guericke.
First functional reflecting telescope constructed by Isaac Newton.
Pressure-cooker: Invented by Denis Papin.
Christiaan Huygens provides the first known description of a piston engine.
Thomas Savery developes a steam-powered water pump: for draining mines
Bartolomeo Cristofori crafts the first piano.
Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit invents the alcohol thermometer.
Thomas Newcomen builds the first commercial steam engine to pump water out of mines. Newcomen's engine, unlike Thomas Savery's, uses a piston.
Thomas Godfrey and John Hadley independently develop the octant
John Kay enables one person to operate a loom with the flying shuttle
Lewis Paul and John Wyatt invent the first mechanized cotton spinning machine.
Benjamin Franklin invents the Franklin stove.
Musschenbroek and Kleist independently develop the Leyden jar, an early form of capacitor.
John Roebuck invents the lead chamber process.
Benjamin Franklin invents the lightning rod.
William Cullen invents the first artificial refrigeration machine.
John Joseph Merlin invents the first  Roller skates.
James Hargreaves invents the spinning jenny.
James Watt invents the improved steam engine utilizing a separate condenser.
Joseph Priestley invents a method for the production of carbonated water.
Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot invents the first steam-powered vehicle capable of carrying passengers, an early car.
Richard Salter invents the earliest known design for a weighing scale.
John Wilkinson invents his boring machine, considered by some to be the first machine tool.
Jesse Ramsden invents the modern screw-cutting lathe.
John Wilkinson invents a mechanical air compressor that would become the prototype for all later mechanical compressors.
Robert Barron invents the first lever tumbler lock.
Hyder Ali of Mysore develops the first metal-cylinder rockets.
Claude de Jouffroy builds the first steamboat.
Joseph-Ralf and Jacques-Étienne Montgolfier build the first manned hot air balloon.
Martinus van Marum is the first to use the electrolysis technique.
Andrew Meikle invents the threshing machine.
Edmund Cartwright invents the power loom.
Thomas Saint invents the sewing machine.
Claude Chappe invents the modern semaphore telegraph.
Eli Whitney invents the modern cotton gin.
Joseph Bramah invents the hydraulic press.
Alois Senefelder invents the lithography printing technique.
Samuel Bentham invents plywood.
George Medhurst invents the first motorized air compressor.
The first paper machine is invented by Louis-Nicolas Robert.
Alessandro Volta invents the voltaic pile, an early form of battery in Italy, based on previous works by Luigi Galvani.
Humphry Davy invents the arc lamp (exact date unclear; not practical as a light source until the invention of efficient electric generators).
Joseph Marie Jacquard develops his automated Jacquard loom.
Richard Trevithick invents the steam locomotive.
Robert Fulton expands water transportation and trade with the workable steamboat.
Nicolas Appert invents the canning process for food.
Abraham-Louis Breguet creates the first wristwatch.
Friedrich Koenig invents the first powered printing press, which was also the first to use a cylinder.
William Reid Clanny pioneered the invention of the safety lamp which he improved in later years. Safety lamps based on Clanny's improved design were used until the adoption of electric lamps.
James Fox invents the modern planing machine, though Matthew Murray of Leeds and Richard Roberts of Manchester have also been credited at times with its invention.
Francis Ronalds builds the first working electric telegraph using electrostatic means.
Robert Stirling invents the Stirling engine.
Baron Karl von Drais invents the dandy horse, an early velocipede and precursor to the modern bicycle.
Marc Isambard Brunel invents the tunnelling shield.

Thomas Blanchard invents the pattern-tracing lathe (actually more like a shaper). The lathe can copy symmetrical shapes and is used for making gun stocks, and later, ax handles. The lathe's patent is in force for 42 years.
Charles Babbage, considered the "father of the computer", begins building the first programmable mechanical computer.
Johann Nikolaus von Dreyse invents the bolt-action rifle.
William Sturgeon invents the electromagnet.
John Walker invents the friction match.
James Sharp invents and goes on to manufacture the first practical gas stove.
James Beaumont Neilson develops the hot blast process.
Patrick Bell invents the reaping machine.
Louis Braille invents the Braille reading system for the blind.
William Mann invents the compound air compressor.
Henry Robinson Palmer is awarded a patent for corrugated galvanised iron.
Edwin Budding invents the lawn mower.
Michael Faraday invents a method of electromagnetic induction. It would be independently invented by Joseph Henry the following year.
Moritz von Jacobi invents the first practical electric motor.
Joseph Henry invents the electromechanical relay.
Samuel Morse invents Morse code.
Moritz von Jacobi invents electrotyping.
William Otis invents the steam shovel.
James Nasmyth invents the steam hammer.
Edmond Becquerel invents a method for the photovoltaic effect, effectively producing the first solar cell.
Charles Goodyear invents vulcanized rubber.
Louis Daguerre invents daguerreotype photography.
John Herschel invents the blueprint.
Alexander Bain devises a printing telegraph.
William Robert Grove invents the first fuel cell.
John Bennet Lawes invents superphosphate, the first man-made fertilizer.
Friedrich Gottlob Keller and, independently, Charles Fenerty come up with the wood pulp method of paper production.
Isaac Charles Johnson invents modern Portland cement.
Henri-Joseph Maus invents the tunnel boring machine.
Ascanio Sobrero invents Nitroglycerin, the first explosive made that was stronger than black powder.
Jonathan J. Couch invents the pneumatic drill.
Linus Yale Sr. invents the first modern pin tumbler lock.
Walter Hunt invents the first repeating rifle to use metallic cartridges (of his own design) and a spring-fed magazine.
James B. Francis invents the Francis turbine.
Walter Hunt invents the Safety pin.
William Armstrong invents the hydraulic accumulator.

George Jennings offers the first public flush toilets, accessible for a penny per visit, and in 1852 receives a UK patent for the single piece, free standing, earthenware, trap plumed, flushing, water-closet.
Robert Bunsen is the first to use a chemical vapor deposition technique.
Elisha Otis invents the safety brake elevator.
Henri Giffard becomes the first person to make a manned, controlled and powered flight using a dirigible.
François Coignet invents reinforced concrete.
James Clerk Maxwell invents the first practical method for color photography, whether chemical or electronic.
Henry Bessemer patents the Bessemer process for making steel, with improvements made by others over the following years.
Alexander Parkes invents parkesine, also known as celluloid, the first man-made plastic.
James Harrison produces the world's first practical ice making machine and refrigerator using the principle of vapour compression in Geelong, Australia.
William Henry Perkin invents mauveine, the first synthetic dye.
Heinrich Geissler invents the Geissler tube.
The phonautograph, the earliest known device for recording sound is patented and invented by Frenchman Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville.
Joseph Swan produces carbon fibers.
Louis Pasteur invents the pasteurization process.
Carl Wilhelm Siemens and Pierre-Émile Martin invented the Siemens-Martin process for making steel.
Alfred Nobel invents dynamite, the first safely manageable explosive stronger than black powder.
Lucien B. Smith invents barbed wire, which Joseph F. Glidden will modify in 1874, leading to the taming of the West and the end of the cowboys.
Polyvinyl chloride, more commonly known as vinyl, is synthesized by German chemist Eugen Baumann
J.E.T. Woods and J. Clark invented stainless steel. Harry Brearley was the first to commercialize it.
Frederick Ransome invents the rotary kiln.
William Crookes, a chemist, invents the Crookes radiometer as the by-product of some chemical research.
Fyodor Pirotsky invents the first electric tram near Saint Petersburg, Russia.
Nicolaus August Otto invents the four-stroke cycle.
Alexander Graham Bell has a patent granted for the telephone. However, other inventors before Bell had worked on the development of the telephone and the invention had several pioneers.
Thomas Edison invents the first working phonograph.
Henry Fleuss is granted a patent for the first practical rebreather.
Lester Allan Pelton invents the Pelton wheel.

Joseph Swan and Thomas Edison both patent a functional incandescent light bulb. Some two dozen inventors had experimented with electric incandescent lighting over the first three-quarters of the 19th century but never came up with a practical design. Swan's, which he had been working on since the 1860s, had a low resistance so was only suited for small installations. Edison designed a high-resistance bulb as part of a large-scale commercial electric lighting utility.
Nikolay Benardos presents carbon arc welding, the first practical arc welding method.
Hiram Maxim invents the recoil-operated Maxim gun, ushering in the age of semi- and fully automatic firearms.
Paul Vieille invents Poudre B, the first smokeless powder for firearms.
Sir Charles Parsons invents the modern steam turbine.
John Kemp Starley invents the modern safety bicycle.
Carl Gassner invents the zinc-carbon battery, the first dry cell battery, making portable electronics practical.
Charles Martin Hall and independently Paul Héroult invent the Hall-Héroult process for economically producing aluminum in 1886.
Karl Benz invents the first petrol or gasoline powered auto-mobile (car).
Carl Josef Bayer invents the Bayer process for the production of alumina.
James Blyth invents the first wind turbine used for generating electricity.
John Stewart MacArthur, working in collaboration with brothers Dr. Robert and Dr. William Forrest develops the process of gold cyanidation.
John J. Loud invents the ballpoint pen.
Thomas Edison and William Kennedy Dickson invents Kinetoscope.

Heinrich Hertz publishes a conclusive proof of James Clerk Maxwell's electromagnetic theory in experiments that also demonstrate the existence of radio waves. The effects of electromagnetic waves had been observed by many people before this but no usable theory explaining them existed until Maxwell.
The first practical pneumatic tire was made by Scotsman John Boyd Dunlop, the patent was from 1847 by Robert William Thomson
Robert Gair would invent the pre-cut cardboard box.
Whitcomb Judson invents the zipper.
Thomas Ahearn invents the electric oven.
Rudolf Diesel invents the diesel engine (although Herbert Akroyd Stuart had experimented with compression ignition before Diesel).
Guglielmo Marconi invents a system of wireless communication using radio waves.
Hans von Pechmann synthesizes polyethylene, now the most common plastic in the world.
Waldemar Jungner invents the rechargeable nickel-cadmium battery (NiCd) as well as the nickel-iron electric storage battery (NiFe) and the rechargeable alkaline silver-cadmium battery (AgCd)
The first Zeppelin is designed by Theodor Kober.
The first motorized cleaner using suction, a powered "vacuum cleaner", is patented independently by Hubert Cecil Booth and David T. Kenney.
The first successful gas turbine is invented by Ægidius Elling.
Édouard Bénédictus invents laminated glass.
First sustained and controlled heavier-than-air powered flight achieved by an airplane flown at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina by Orville and Wilbur Wright. See Claims to the first powered flight.
The Fleming valve, the first vacuum tube and diode, is invented by John Ambrose Fleming.
The first free flight of a rotary-wing aircraft is carried out by Paul Cornu.
Leo Baekeland invents bakelite,  the first plastic made from synthetic components.
Cellophane is invented by Jacques E. Brandenberger.
Fritz Haber invents the Haber process.
The first instantaneous transmission of images, or television broadcast, is carried out by Georges Rignoux and A. Fournier.
The cloud chamber, the first particle detector, is invented by Charles Thomson Rees Wilson.
The first use of articulated trams by Boston Elevated Railway.
The Bergius process is developed by Friedrich Bergius.
The Kaplan turbine is invented by Viktor Kaplan.
Harry Brearley invents a process to create Martensitic stainless steel, initially labelled Rustless Steel, later marketed as Staybrite, and AISI Type 420.

The first operational military tanks are designed in Great Britain and France. They are used in battle from 1916 and 1917 respectively. The designers in Great Britain are Walter Wilson and William Tritton and in France, Eugène Brillié. (Although it is known that vehicles incorporating at least some of the features of the tank were designed in a number of countries from 1903 onward, none reached a practical form.)
The Czochralski process, widely used for the production of single crystal silicon, is invented by Jan Czochralski.
The crystal oscillator is invented by Alexander M. Nicholson using a crystal of Rochelle Salt although his priority was disputed by Walter Guyton Cady.

The Yagi-Uda Antenna or simply Yagi Antenna is invented by Shintaro Uda of Tohoku Imperial University, assisted by his colleague Hidetsugu Yagi. The Yagi Antenna was widely used during World War II. After the war they saw extensive development as home television antennas.
Robert H. Goddard launches the first liquid fueled rocket.
Harry Ferguson, patents the Three-point hitch equipment linkage system for tractors.
John Logie Baird demonstrates the world's first live working television system.
The quartz clock is invented by Warren Marrison and J.W. Horton at Bell Telephone Laboratories.

Penicillin is first observed to exude antibiotic substances by Nobel laureate Alexander Fleming. Development of medicinal penicillin is attributed to a team of medics and scientists including Howard Walter Florey, Ernst Chain and Norman Heatley.
Frank Whittle formally submitted his ideas for a turbo-jet engine. In October 1929, he developed his ideas further. On 16 January 1930, Whittle submitted his first patent (granted in 1932).
Philo Farnsworth demonstrates the first practical electronic television to the press.
The ball screw is invented by Rudolph G. Boehm.
The Supersonic combusting ramjet — Frank Whittle.
The Phase-contrast microscopy is invented by Frits Zernike.
The electron microscope is invented by Ernst Ruska.
FM radio is patented by inventor Edwin H. Armstrong.
Nylon, the first fully synthetic fiber is produced by Wallace Carothers while working at DuPont.
Z1, built by Konrad Zuse, is the first freely programmable computer in the world.

Nuclear fission discovered in experiment by chemists Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann and physicists Lise Meitner and Otto Robert Frisch. The German nuclear energy project was based on this research. The Tube Alloys project and, subsequently, the Manhattan Project and the Soviet atomic bomb project were influenced by this research.
G. S. Yunyev or Naum Gurvich invented the electric current defibrillator

Pu-239 isotope (isotope of plutonium) a form of matter existing with the capacity for use as a destructive element (because the isotope has an exponentially increasing spontaneous fissile decay) within nuclear devices — Glenn Seaborg.
John Randall and Harry Boot would develop the high power, microwave generating, cavity magnetron, later applied to commercial Radar and Microwave oven appliances.
Polyester is invented by John Rex Whinfield and James Dickson.
The V-2 rocket, the world's first long range ballistic missile, developed by engineer Wernher von Braun.
The atomic bomb is developed by the Manhattan Project and swiftly deployed in August 1945 in the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, effectively ending World War II.
Percy Spencer, while employed at Raytheon, would patent a magnetron based microwave oven.
James Martin invents the ejector seat, inspired by the death of his friend and test pilot Captain Valentine Baker in an aeroplane crash in 1942.
Holography is invented by Dennis Gabor.
Floyd Farris and J.B. Clark (Stanolind Oil and Gas Corporation) invents hydraulic fracturing technology.
The first transistor, a bipolar point-contact transistor, is invented by John Bardeen and Walter Brattain under the supervision of William Shockley at Bell Labs.
The first atomic clock is developed at the National Bureau of Standards.

Basic oxygen steelmaking is developed by Robert Durrer. The vast majority of steel manufactured in the world is produced using the basic oxygen furnace; in 2000, it accounted for 60% of global steel output.
Bertie the Brain, debatably the first video game, is displayed to the public at the Canadian National Exhibition.
The Toroidal chamber with axial magnetic fields (the Tokamak) is developed by Igor E. Tamm and Andrei D. Sakharov.
The float glass process is developed by Alastair Pilkington.
The first thermonuclear weapon is developed.
The first video tape recorder, a helical scan recorder, is invented by Norikazu Sawazaki.

Invention of the solar battery by Bell Telephone scientists, Calvin Souther Fuller, Daryl Chapin and Gerald Pearson capturing the Sun's power. First practical means of collecting energy from the Sun and turning it into a current of electricity.
The hovercraft is patented by Christopher Cockerell.
The intermodal container is developed by Malcom McLean.
The hard disk drive is invented by IBM.
The laser and optical amplifier are invented and named by Gordon Gould and Charles Townes. The laser and optical amplifier are foundational to powering the Internet.
The first personal computer used by one person and controlled by a keyboard, the IBM 610, is invented in 1957 by IBM.
The first artificial satellite, Sputnik 1, is launched.
The integrated circuit is independently invented by Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce.

The MOSFET (MOS transistor) is invented by the Egyptian Mohamed Atalla and the Korean Dawon Kahng at Bell Labs. It is used in almost all modern electronic products. It was smaller, faster, more reliable and cheaper to manufacture than earlier bipolar transistors, leading to a revolution in computers, controls and communication.
The first functioning laser is invented by Theodore Maiman.
The first electronic cigarette is created by Herbert A. Gilbert. Hon Lik is often credited with its invention as he developed the modern electronic cigarette and was the first to commercialize it.
Shinkansen, the first high-speed rail commercial passenger service.
Kevlar is invented by Stephanie Kwolek at DuPont.
ARPANET and the NPL network implement packet switching, drawing on the concepts and designs of Donald Davies, and Paul Baran.

Public-key cryptography is invented and developed by James H. Ellis, Clifford Cocks, Malcolm J. Williamson, Whitfield Diffie, Martin Hellman, Ralph Merkle, Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir, Leonard Adleman, et al.
The pocket calculator is invented.

The first single-chip microprocessor, the Intel 4004, is invented. Its development was led by Federico Faggin, using his silicon-gate MOS technology. This led to the personal computer (PC) revolution.
The first space station, Salyut 1 is launched.
The first video game console, used primarily for playing video games on a TV, is the Magnavox Odyssey.
The first fiber optic communication systems were developed by Optelecom.
The first commercial graphical user interface is introduced in 1973 on the Xerox Alto. The modern GUI is later popularized by the Xerox Star and Apple Lisa.
The first capacitive touchscreen is developed at CERN.
The Transmission Control Program is proposed by Vinton Cerf and Robert E. Kahn, building on the work of Louis Pouzin, creating the basis for the modern Internet.

The lithium-ion battery is invented by M. Stanley Whittingham, and further developed in the 1980s and 1990s by John B. Goodenough, Rachid Yazami and Akira Yoshino. It has impacted modern consumer electronics and electric vehicles.
Dr Walter Gilbert and Frederick Sanger invented a new DNA sequencing method for which they won the Nobel Prize.
The first self-driving car that did not rely upon rails or wires under the road is designed by the Tsukuba Mechanical Engineering Laboratory.
The Global Positioning System (GPS) enters service. While not the first Satellite navigation system, it is the first to enter widespread civilian use.
The first handheld game console with interchangeable game cartridges, the Microvision is released.
Public dialup information, messaging and e-commerce services, were pioneered through CompuServe and RadioShack's MicroNET, and the UK's Post Office Telecommunications Prestel services.
Flash memory (both NOR and NAND types) is invented by Fujio Masuoka while working for Toshiba. It is formally introduced to the public in 1984.
The first reusable spacecraft, the Space Shuttle undergoes test flights ahead of full operation in 1982.
Kane Kramer develops the credit card sized, IXI digital media player.

A CD-ROM contains data accessible to, but not writable by, a computer for data storage and music playback. The 1985 Yellow Book standard developed by Sony and Philips adapted the format to hold any form of binary data.
Direct to home satellite television transmission, with the launch of Sky One service.
The first laptop computer is launched, the 8/16-bit Epson HX-20.
Stereolithography is invented by Chuck Hull.
The first commercially available cell phone, the DynaTAC 8000X, is created by Motorola.
DNA profiling is pioneered by Alec Jeffreys.
Karlheinz Brandenburg would publish the audio compression algorithms that would be standardised as the: MPEG-1, layer 3 (mp3), and later the MPEG-2, layer 7 Advanced Audio Compression (AAC).
The World Wide Web is invented by computer scientist Tim Berners-Lee.
The Neo Geo AES becomes the first video game system to launch that used Memory Cards
The first search engine invented was “Archie”, created by Alan Emtage a student at McGill University in Montreal
The first commercial flash-based solid-state drive is launched by SunDisk.
The first sim card is developed by Munich smart-card maker Giesecke & Devrient,
IBM Simon, World's first smartphone is developed by IBM.
First generation of Bluetooth is developed by Ericsson Mobile. A form of data communication on short distances between electronic devices.
A Tetris variant on the Hagenuk MT-2000 device becomes the first mobile game
DVD is an optical disc storage format, invented and developed by Philips, Sony, Toshiba, and Panasonic in 1995. DVDs offer higher storage capacity than compact discs while having the same dimensions.
Match.com launches as the first dating site ever and is the number 1 most visited dating site in the US
Waiter.com launches as the first online food ordering service
Ciena deploys the first commercial wave division multiplexing system in partnership with Sprint. This created the massive capacity of the internet.
Mobile web was first commercially offered in Finland on the Nokia 9000 Communicator phone and it was also the first phone with texting
Bolt and Six Degrees (1997) both become the first social media sites
The first weblog, a discussion or informational website, is created by Jorn Barger, later shortened to "blog" in 1999 by Peter Merholz.
The first portable MP3 player is released by SaeHan Information Systems.
The first digital video recorder (DVR), the TiVo, is launched by Xperi.
NTT DoCoMo launches i-mode, the first integrated Online App store for mobile phones
Sony develops the first prototypes for the Blu-ray optical disc format. The first prototype player was released in 2004.

First documented placement of Geocaching, an outdoor recreational activity, in which participants use a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver or mobile device and other navigational techniques to hide and seek containers, took place on May 3, 2000, by Dave Ulmer of Beavercreek, Oregon.
The Xbox Launches and is the first game console with internal storage

First podcast, invented by Adam Curry and Dave Winer, is a program made available in digital format for download over the Internet and it usually features one or more recurring hosts engaged in a discussion about a particular topic or current event.
YouTube, the first popular video-streaming site, was founded
Netflix debuted the first popular video-on-demand service
The Bank of Scotland develops the worlds first banking app
SoundCloud, the first on-demand service to focus on music is debuted

First Kindle introduced by Amazon (company) founder and CEO Jeff Bezos, who instructed the company's employees to build the world's best e-reader before Amazon's competitors could. Amazon originally used the codename Fiona for the device. This hardware evolved from the original Kindle introduced in 2007 and the Kindle DX (with its larger 9.7" screen) introduced in 2009.
Satoshi Nakamoto develops the first blockchain.
The Zeebo is released becoming the first digital-only video game console
The first solar sail based spacecraft, IKAROS.
The first quantum machine
The first synthetic organism, Mycoplasma laboratorium is created by the J. Craig Venter Institute.
Twitch, launches as the first live-streaming service.
HIV treatment as prevention (HPTN 052)
Discovery of the Higgs boson
Cancer immunotherapy

The first known "NFT", Quantum, was created by Kevin McCoy and Anil Dash in May 2014, that explicitly linked a non-fungible, tradable blockchain marker to a work of art, via on-chain metadata (enabled by Namecoin).
CRISPR genome-editing method
The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory makes the first observation of gravitational waves, fulfilling Einstein's prediction
Single cell sequencing
IBM launches IBM Q System One, its first integrated quantum computing system for commercial use.
The first RNA vaccine to be approved by public health medicines regulators is co-developed by Pfizer and BioNTech for COVID-19.
Pfizer develops the world's first pill for COVID
